comment_text: Skillshare is offering SciShow viewers two months of unlimited access to Skillshare for free! Try it here: https://skl.sh/scishow-14

This is so fascinating! This condensed about 6 hrs of research I have been doing trying to figure out some major pains my doctor, surgeon, physical therapist, chiropractor, massage therapist kept calling pinched nerves! I have suffered for 12 yrs.. it's been chronic for 16 months. I go to the spine institute in Charleston Tuesday. Now I am considering cancelling it because I have been polishing, massaging with butter knife handle.. spoons.. foam cylinders and have found so much relief! I had primarily {and all the specialist} on my core and up. I started at the bottom of my feet. Dang they were tight! And I have worn yoga toes stretchers off n on for 12 years because bad feet run in my mom's family. Mine doesn't hurt, I just use the spacers as preventative purposes. When I got to my legs . Holy moly the upper back of them and my butt cheeks were way too tight but I have been doing pretty good at loosening them. But it's taken so much time reading and watching videos {I have shared this one with my mom and sisters because it's so condensed and hits all the important points. It's made them think I am less crazy or just grasping for anything to help!} I plan on learning everything I can about it because not only is it improving my pain level but it's just amazing! I can't believe they didn't study the 'filler' 75 yrs ago! Tossing aside the very key to so many people's discomfort and pain! Thank you for sharing this! I subscribed. I hope to learn more. Hope you have more videos like this without trying to sell me something bawhahaha. Because I studied to be a paralegal before www lmbo. So research is my thang🤷😜

Dr Robert Schleip is one of the leading experts about fascia and offers us an understanding on how we can train fascia to avoid injuries and increase our potentials within strength, movement, healing and much more.

I like what he presents about 4 distinct ways of training/treating our fascia that connect all of us together and make us (with our muscles, nervesystem etc) move and restore in often miraculous ways.


1. training elasticity - by jumping, bouncing etc (like kids naturally do)
2. mindful stretching - like yin yoga, in a variable range of motions.
3. nutritional focus - giving fluid and nutrients to our fascia, joins, muscle etc with everything from trigger point balls, bodywork to sports massasje.
4. space awareness - sensory information about where we have all our body parts related to gravity and our perception of reality (how our emotions and postures also plays out in functional ways)

Dear friends, everyone is capable of understanding the tissues at the fascial level in the most simplistic of ways. It simply requires some very subtle, purposeful motions. The kind of motion that our body requires on a moment to moment basis. Imagine if you can apply what ‘stretching’ is but use it in a far more integrative process. Imagine taking this a step further, and experiencing the transformation as an active form of meditation. All of this is possible. Please feel free to visit our channel for inspiration on how to get started. Opportunity is all around you, you just have to feel it to see it. Godspeed.

Fascia, the Sensory Information Organ

The human body is covered with a complex interconnective structure that forms into the embedded liquid crystalline matrix of the connective tissue network that is called the Fascia. This connective tissue network connects into every major system in the human body and its purpose is to relay sensory information and instruction sets throughout the multiple layers of tissue matrices, connecting internal and outer circuitry into the multidimensional spiritual layers. It is the Fascia Crystalline Network that saturates our cells with multidimensional light and sound, acting as the most important energetic communication system in our physical body. Specifically, the fascial liquid crystalline network connects directly with all of the horizontal triad bodies that make up the entire Radial Body system, and the main 12 meridians that intersect with the 12 axiatonal lines, which further communicate and send messaging into the brain and throughout the nervous system.

Most are unaware that the extensive connective tissue of the fascia network is the manifestation of the pre-matter instruction set of tissue capsules and complex crystalline webbing that make up the multidimensional identity spheres energetic structure of the Radial Body.

When the crystalline matrix is properly hydrated in the human body, the entire living system is bound within the water molecules and becomes electrified, transmitting energy signals at much faster speeds than the central nervous system. Thus, the fascia network becomes a semiconductor that is conductive to electromagnetism, sparking protons and electrons to help create ions which are intrinsic to the biological ionization process of ascension that generates plasmic light. The biological ionization process is what builds and strengthens the lightbody, preparing the inner dwelling of our consciousness bodies to receive and embody liquid plasmic light.

By understanding the piezoelectric effects of the fascial network, life force energy can be circulated to move through blockages in the meridian system and further support biological ionization. Additionally, the fascia network receives the energetic pulses we receive from the Cosmic Order that has been filtered down as energy transmissions made into the layers of the Radial body, which are then further filtered down to be transmitted into the horizontal triad bodies or dimensionalized shields. The fascia network acts as the capacitor needed to absorb the energetic current when our biology is being subjected to the added exposures of electromagnetic surges and intergalactic plasmas that are currently transmitting during the planetary ascension. It modulates the down stepping of frequency activation in the ways that our physical body can handle or survive, so that we don’t blow our circuits.

Fascia is intelligently designed to integrate all component parts of the human body into a holistic living matrix, it is the primary organ system that is designed to unify all bodily systems in order to synthesize physical functions into achieving energetic balance or homeostasis. When there is an impact made to one smaller section of the fascia, it communicates throughout all of the interconnected structures, thus, the entire living system of the body is affected.

The Fascia crystalline network acts as the transport messenger of intelligent information, such as that made from encountering stimulus from the outer world by communicating that data to the inner energetic landscape of the entire human body. The information that is collected from the environmental conditions are sent back into the cells of the human body in order to determine what genes are being transcribed within the cell and what instruction sets are needed for an assortment of functions to optimize the bodily systems. As an example, the cells in the body produce metabolic waste products that require detoxification, and the fascia network delivers the information needed in the cell to cell network to help facilitate the cellular detoxification process and then help to deliver nutrients to where they are most needed. The fascia network performs the same function for releasing and clearing the energetic equivalents of toxins, such as implants, AI signals and energy parasites, which includes the realms of negative entity attachments and alien hybridization overlays. These classifications are considered energetic contaminants that require detoxification from the organic crystalline body and consciousness, which have negative impacts similar to unreleased metabolic waste that become toxic.

I've heard of something similar in regards to improving stab-protection of body armor. Bullet resistant vests are great at stopping common handgun bullets, but other objects like knifes can easily pierce the vest (bullets are typically soft and deform, while knives don't). A few years ago, there was a study of a milky liquid with unusual properties: the molecules can move around, slowly, but when a quick force is applied, they lock together. Researchers are hoping that when Kevlar is treated with this liquid, it will improve the protection for the person wearing the vest.

After two decades of living in nearly constant pain, with frequent injuries such as sprains, dislocations, and unidentifiable abnormalities, with very few physical "proof" of my invisible illnesses, I was diagnosed at 24 with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome. Years later I found a specialist and was diagnosed MCAS and POTS at 34. It is fantastic that fascia is finally getting the attention it is, as conditions like mine are so poorly understood. The triad of conditions; EDS., mast cell activation syndrome, and postural orthostatic hypotension together affect the entire body. I have always intuitively understood that the problems I have physically are only the measurable parts of my conditions and that there are hormonal and chemical problems lurking under the surface. Since those things are difficult to measure or test, maybe testing the fascia could provide more evidence and suggest possible treatments.  The source of these is a mutation on the MTHFR gene. I hope that biotech will eventually have solutions to conditions like mine.

It's really good to see that you guys are following the wave as modern medicine gets better (again) at remembering that physical, mechanical, tensile forces in the body do actually exist and do actually do things. A couple of years ago after I had serious flu my nose kept dripping constantly day and night. At first my doctor said I had post nasal drip, after a couple of months he sent me to ENT where the consultant tested the fluid that was dripping and said it was cerebrospinal fluid.

 I then had a cranial MRI. The conclusion was that I had hag viral encephalitis that damaged a small 1cm circle of my skull at the back of my nose and also tore the meninges between the brain and sinus.

I was told that I needed urgent surgery to repair the hole in my skull as my brain was exposed and could easily be infected.

To repair the hole a small piece of fascia was removed from my left leg and used to patch the hole. It was a three and a half hour operation. After the surgery I had no pain in my head, but my leg where the piece of fascia had been removed was very painful it was a week before I could walk without a walking frame and I needed a walking stick for at least a month after that.

As a personal trainer for the past 25 years the fitness industry has embraced dealing with fascia in its ability to study posture, stability, flexibility/mobility, Jandas sub systems, Anatomy Train's fascial line syatems etc.  Serge Gracovesky in his famous 2007 presentation at the Fascial convention in Boston really outlined the importance of fascia in spinal stability using models to detail its role.
My intestine perforated and I felt it happen. It was incredibly painful but the intestine doesn’t have pain receptors so I always wondered why it hurt so much. Was it the fascia sensing the damage?

All fun and games when it does its job properly. But when it doesn't.. Man...fascia can make you suffer. In my case, the fascia around my lower leg muscles was too tight. So whenever i ran for too long, my own muscles would try and crush my bones. The fascia would also stretch and tear in places. Only found out about that wonderful problem when i attempted basic training in the canadian forces...
Oh, and another reason it wasn't really well know or studied before. It's pretty much invisible with most scans. They have to rip you open to take a good look most of the time.
Once we understand how fascia works, we'll be able to genetically engineer shapeshifting into a creature.

It's delicious!

And as I realize just how that sounds, let me explain haha... When we cook connective tissue, the collagen and elastin break down: the collagen is what makes gravy so dang good. And even when you aren't cooking joints, the fascia wrapping all those muscles still has enough collagen to make your pork chop or your steak or your pot roast have that umami. (Or, it's a very large component of it - don't want to oversimplify.)

I have Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, a genetic connective tissue disorder in which there is a problem with how the body produces collagen. It's well-known that a high proportion of people with EDS also have POTS, a form of dysautonomia (or dysfunction in the autonomic nervous system). However, I've always heard that we didn't know why. I had to pause the video at 4:02 to FREAK OUT because that seems like it explains it...problem is, there's so little research on EDS that no matter how obvious it seems, it's unlikely that anyone will actually do a peer-reviewed study to prove it. :/

In my work, knowing intuitively how the fascia responds to my hands, isn't everything... but it is 90% of it :D

Some notes:
-- fascia not only varies its ratios of collagen within it... but responds to chronic stimuli by conforming that makeup to whatever the behavior requires, i.e. a heavy equipment operator who moves a joystick seated 12 hrs a day for 20 yrs who can't stand without pain (body conforms to seated as its 'normal' -- which is patently abnormal, but behavior = what the body adapts / specializes for). Changing his fascia along with flaws in his muscles/connective tissue, can resolve even decades-old pain / ROM issues.

-- you can change you own fascia very, very easily -- even in cases where muscular bodywork fails, competent fascial work can and has resolved many issues on my table.

-- fascia responds to very light pressure in a certain way -- I can't be more specific than that, as there are so many caveats. But heavy pressure like Swedish is what fascia responds to by becoming less motile -- fascial work rarely requires more pressure than the weight of a limb on a roller ;)

My fascia by my left calf was cut, and now I can’t run. I think the proprioception of my left leg was seriously messed up. It does feel a little weird. The fact I care so much may be proof of its effect on our emotions. Fortunately, my right leg still has its fascia, so I can still drive safely!
I’m missing a lot of unnecessary, but very useful, body parts. My fascia was cut out of me, my omentum was removed because of an infection from a surgery, I only have one ovary (but it’s okay, you only really need one), my appendix was removed, along with 6 inches of intestines (any more, and they would have given me one of those bags to aid in digestion!). But the only thing that really bothers me is my fascia. Anyway, enough whining! Thanks for the video, I love learning about fascia (and the rest of the human body)!
